data.text: @Jacob_Pfeifer Yea my store isn’t eligible to receive the vaccine till phase 2 and only one of our stores has a refrigerator approved to store the vaccines.

@aSQUIDsurvives Thanks Jake ❤️. Have you gotten yours yet?

I think we have -70 freezers where other providers may not. So healthcare workers are getting Pfizer and nursing homes are getting Moderna to start. Soon both will be available at Via Christi tho.
@Jacob_Pfeifer Interesting to see that they are using the Pfizer shot over Moderna. I’m happy to see you being able to get vaccinated.
My second dose is scheduled for Monday January 18th. I'll post and update after that!

About 4 hours after getting the shot I had soreness in my shoulder. Again, very similar to the feeling I get after a flu shot. Later in the evening I felt like I might be developing a small fever but I took my temp and was at 98.1°. I woke up this morning feeling fine.

The shot was similar to a flu shot. I chose my right shoulder, felt the needle prick, and that was it. I was monitored for 15 minutes, reminded to schedule my second dose in 19-23 days, and I was on my way. The whole thing took about 45 minutes.

When I arrived at SF, I was given an info sheet on the Pfizer vaccine and asked a series of questions to determine if I would need a 15 or 30 minute observation period post-vaccine. I think the main concern is people who have had an allergic reaction to other vaccines in the past

But I thought I could at least document my experience for others who are curious how it all works. 

On Tuesday, I got a text saying my department was eligible for a vaccine. Following the link in the text I was able to schedule an appointment.

1) Some of my co-workers go into nursing homes daily for lab work. 2) Ascension Via Christi told me if I passed, they don't know when I would be eligible again. 3) I'm being selfish. It's hard not to daydream about life after being vaccinated.
